posts.cooked: We need your opinion. The team wants to increase the elevator's height and decided to shorten the inner (smallest) stage by 2 inches. The elevator consists of two stages, and its height must be greater than 0. Will the additional height be 4 inches, 2 inches, or 0 inches? Our team doesn't know the exact outcome and is seeking your help through a poll.

posts.name: Arshon Bozorgi
posts.cooked:
Making that stage smaller wonâ€™t gain you any height unless your mechanism is specifically mounted on the bottom.

Otherwise, changing the size of that stage wonâ€™t affect the height unless the mounting point of whatever mechanism you have on there is moved higher too.

Edit after reading accepted solution: My response assumes that all stages are already at their maximum extension.

For more context, the elevator is from the Thrifty Bot, and the mechanism will be mounted on this grey frame attached to the inner stage. I have also gotten a value from the CAD, which I think is correct but haven't revealed yet.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: The top of the elevator will rise by 4 inches. Additionally, the bottom of the mechanism will move 2 inches closer to the top of the elevator.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: When considering a cascade lift system, it is either 0 or 4 units. With two stages, the movement per stage doubles. However, if the first stage reaches its maximum capacity, even with modifications, the total extension cannot be increased. If continuously adjusted, the stages' extensions do not necessarily need to be equal.
Can you send a photo of it fully extended?
The first stage is not yet at its full capacity but is approaching it closely, making it the limiting factor for two units.
No photo unfortunately, but I have a poorly shot video titled "The Great Debate" available on YouTube.

posts.name: Steven Pearson
posts.cooked: Your elevator stage will move 2 inches more, but that doesnâ€™t necessarily mean gaining 2 inches in height. If your mechanism is attached at the top of the elevator, it will begin 2 inches lower but end at the same level. If itâ€™s placed at the bottom, it will start and finish at the same point but effectively rise 2 inches. If mounted midway, it will start slightly lower and ascend to a higher position.

posts.name: Alex Kempen
posts.cooked: Reducing the height of the carriage adds 4 extra inches. Since the system is rigged 1:1, doubling the movement affects both components. When the carriage moves 2 inches, the first stage does too, reducing overlap by 2 inches when fully extended. Overlaps remain consistent, maintaining system stability. Proper adjustment ensures full operation, avoiding issues like unintended height changes due to improper mounting.
The product works perfectly. I love it!

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: The extra 2 inches the first stage travels is taken out of the overlap between the first stage and the base stage when the elevator is all the way up. This creates a potential constraint that may limit the height gain of the inner stage relative to the base. On a Thrifty elevator there is a crossmember on the base stage that holds anchors for the inner stage cascade rope. It is possible depending on geometry that the rope pulleys on the bottom of the middle stage do not have 2 more inches they can travel before hitting the rope anchors. If that is the case the overall height gain will be limited to 2 times the additional height the middle stage can be raised relative to the base due to physical constraints. It may be possible to modify the rope anchor design if the anchors constrain the movement but this would need to be a part of the redesign. There is also the issue that reducing the distance between the bearings on both stages increases the force on those bearings when the elevator experiences lateral loads. Reducing a typical 6 inch span to 4 inches might not result in failure depending on the mass of the end effector on the elevator and how the robot accelerates with the elevator at various states of extension but it increases the potential for failure. This is where the question of can I make this change starts to intersect with the question of should I make this change.

We held an internal poll and debated for an additional 30 minutes, and these are the results. The vote is incomplete by two inches and includes a Latin and chemistry teacher who were passing by during our discussion.

accepted_answer.excerpt:
Reducing the height of the carriage should result in 4 extra inches of height. 
The height gain is multiplied by 2x since the carriage is rigged 1:1 with the first stage, so when the carriage itself is able to travel 2 more inches relative to the first stage, then the first stage will also travel 2 …
